docs.abstract: US offers resolution condemning internatl communism as foreign intervention and urging joint action against it when needed; urges Conf declare that Communist control of any country would justify action under existing treaties; urges all Govts identify and keep track of Communist agents and propagandists within own territories and exch pertinent data; resolution based on stands taken at Bogota Conf and '51 Foreign Mins meeting; avoids naming Guatemala or urging internatl probe; adoption in present form seen; Uruguayan milder proposal to bar totalitarian intervention noted

docs.snippet: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 7 -- The Argentine Government, in an attempt to keep the Brazilian market as one of the largest out lets for its wheat crop, has offered to sell at $76 to $78 a ton. This was reported today by Ataliba Barcante, chief of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 7 -- The Argentine Government, in an attempt to keep the Brazilian market as one of the largest out lets for its wheat crop, has offered to sell at $76 to $78 a ton. This was reported today by Ataliba Barcante, chief of the Brazilian wheat development program.
docs.abstract: Argentina offers wheat at $76-78 a ton in move to keep outlet

headline.main: Argentina Dickers With Brazil on Wheat In Move to Keep One of Largest Outlets

docs.snippet: Problems facing adoption agencies and adoptive parents in the United States are mirrored in Europe, Canada and South America, a United Nations survey reveals. Findings of a study of adoption practices in fifteen countries were released yesterday by...
docs.lead_paragraph: Problems facing adoption agencies and adoptive parents in the United States are mirrored in Europe, Canada and South America, a United Nations survey reveals. Findings of a study of adoption practices in fifteen countries were released yesterday by the United Nations' Department of Social Affairs in collaboration with the International Union for Child Welfare.
docs.abstract: Child Welfare Union survey of 15 countries practices for UN Soc Affairs Dept reveals problems are like those in US

headline.main: ADOPTION SURVEY RELEASED BY U. N.; Study of 15 Countries Finds Problems Abroad Akin to Difficulties in U. S.
